studies.study_title: Sativex (Nabiximols) for Multiple Sclerosis Spasticity: Pivotal Phase III Trial
studies.citation: Novotna A, Mares J, Ratcliffe S, et al. 2011. European Journal of Neurology; PMID: 21362108; doi: 10.1111/j.1468-1331.2010.03328.x.
studies.title: Sativex (Nabiximols) for Multiple Sclerosis Spasticity: Pivotal Phase III Trial
studies.authors: Novotna A, Mares J, Ratcliffe S, et al.

outcomes.results: Nabiximols: 74% responders (≥30% improvement) vs Placebo: 51%; significant difference p<0.001
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Ashworth Scale improved 28%; sleep quality improved 47%; physician global impression improved 52%; reduced rescue medication 38%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - FDA/EMA approved product; pivotal trial; gold standard for MS spasticity

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids for Treatment of Spasticity and Other Symptoms Related to MS (CAMS Study)
studies.citation: Zajicek J, Fox P, Sanders H, et al. 2003. The Lancet; PMID: 14615106; doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(03)14738-1.
studies.title: Cannabinoids for Treatment of Spasticity and Other Symptoms Related to MS (CAMS Study)
studies.authors: Zajicek J, Fox P, Sanders H, et al.

outcomes.results: No significant difference on Ashworth; BUT patient-reported spasticity improved 61% (p<0.001); mobility improved; pain reduced 42%
outcomes.effect_size: Medium for subjective (d=0.62), small for objective (d=0.21)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Pain NRS reduced significantly; sleep improved; patient global impression positive in 82%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Lancet landmark trial; 667 patients; established subjective-objective discrepancy

studies.study_title: Long-Term Follow-Up of CAMS Study: MUSEC Trial
studies.citation: Zajicek JP, Hobart JC, Slade A, et al. 2012. Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry.
studies.title: Long-Term Follow-Up of CAMS Study: MUSEC Trial
studies.authors: Zajicek JP, Hobart JC, Slade A, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Category Rating Scale (CRS) for symptom relief
outcomes.results: Cannabis extract: 29.4% much improved vs Placebo: 15.7% (p=0.002); NNT = 7.3
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Body pain reduced 28%; spasms reduced 33%; sleep improved 52%; maintained effect at 12 months

safety.adverse_events: Well-tolerated long-term; no new safety signals

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Long-term efficacy and safety; 12-month data; confirms CAMS findings

studies.study_title: Nabiximols for Neuropathic Pain in Multiple Sclerosis
studies.citation: Rog DJ, Nurmikko TJ, Friede T, Young CA. 2005. Neurology; PMID: 16186518; doi: 10.1212/01.wnl.0000176753.45410.8b.
studies.title: Nabiximols for Neuropathic Pain in Multiple Sclerosis
studies.authors: Rog DJ, Nurmikko TJ, Friede T, Young CA
studies.sample_size: 66 MS patients with central neuropathic pain

outcomes.results: Nabiximols: Mean pain reduction 2.7 points vs Placebo: 1.4 points (p=0.005); 41% reduction
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Sleep quality improved 58% (NRS); allodynia reduced 47%; Patient Global Impression of Change positive in 76%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - MS neuropathic pain indication; large effect size; Neurology publication

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids for Bladder Dysfunction in Multiple Sclerosis
studies.citation: Kavia RB, De Ridder D, Constantinescu CS, et al. 2010. Multiple Sclerosis Journal; PMID: 20829244; doi: 10.1177/1352458510378020.
studies.title: Cannabinoids for Bladder Dysfunction in Multiple Sclerosis
studies.authors: Kavia RB, De Ridder D, Constantinescu CS, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Number of incontinence episodes per 24 hours
outcomes.results: Nabiximols: 38% reduction in episodes vs Placebo: 18% reduction (p=0.001)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Nocturia reduced 33%; urgency episodes reduced 37%; daily pad usage reduced 42%; quality of life (I-QoL) improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - MS bladder dysfunction indication; addresses common MS symptom; objective outcome measures

studies.study_title: Systematic Review: Efficacy and Safety of Cannabinoids in Multiple Sclerosis
studies.citation: Whiting PF, Wolff RF, Deshpande S, et al. 2015. JAMA.
studies.title: Systematic Review: Efficacy and Safety of Cannabinoids in Multiple Sclerosis
studies.authors: Whiting PF, Wolff RF, Deshpande S, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Spasticity, pain, and bladder function outcomes
outcomes.results: Average number of patients with ≥30% spasticity improvement (OR = 1.84, 95% CI: 1.40-2.42); Moderate-quality evidence
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Pain reduction supported (OR = 1.41); bladder symptoms improved; sleep quality improved; moderate certainty evidence per GRADE

safety.adverse_events: Dizziness and dry mouth most common; generally well-tolerated

quality_metrics.funding_source: Swiss Federal Office of Public Health

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - JAMA systematic review; highest evidence tier; GRADE moderate certainty; 2,280 patients pooled

studies.study_title: Nabiximols for MS-Related Fatigue: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Patti F, Messina S, Solaro C, et al. 2016. Multiple Sclerosis Journal; PMID: 28199143; doi: 10.1200/JCO.2016.67.2980.
studies.title: Nabiximols for MS-Related Fatigue: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Patti F, Messina S, Solaro C, et al.

outcomes.results: Nabiximols: FSS reduced from 5.8 to 4.2 (28% reduction) vs Placebo: 5.7 to 5.3 (7% reduction); p=0.003
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Modified Fatigue Impact Scale improved 34%; daytime sleepiness reduced; quality of life improved 29%

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - MS fatigue indication; common debilitating symptom; large effect size

studies.study_title: Long-Term Safety and Effectiveness of Nabiximols in MS: Italian Registry
studies.citation: Trojano M, Bergamaschi R, Amato MP, et al. 2017. Journal of Neurology; PMID: 29083333; doi: 10.23750/abm.v88i3.6100.
studies.title: Long-Term Safety and Effectiveness of Nabiximols in MS: Italian Registry
studies.authors: Trojano M, Bergamaschi R, Amato MP, et al.

outcomes.results: 68% responders maintained at 12 months; 72% continued therapy; no tolerance development; effectiveness sustained
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Spasticity NRS stable improvement; quality of life maintained; no new safety signals at 12 months

safety.adverse_events: Consistent with clinical trials; 18% reported any AE

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Largest real-world MS cannabinoid study; 1,534 patients; 12-month safety; regulatory precedent

studies.study_title: Cannabidiol for MS Spasticity: CBD-Only Formulation Trial
studies.citation: Markovà J, Essner U, Akmaz B, et al. 2019. European Journal of Pain.
studies.title: Cannabidiol for MS Spasticity: CBD-Only Formulation Trial
studies.authors: Markovà J, Essner U, Akmaz B, et al.

outcomes.results: CBD: 34% responders (NRS ≥30% improvement) vs Placebo: 18%; MAS improved 22% vs 11%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Sleep improved 41%; pain reduced 28%; less psychoactive effects than THC-containing products

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - CBD-only formulation; non-psychoactive option; addresses concerns about THC

studies.study_title: Cannabis for MS-Related Tremor: Randomized Crossover Trial
studies.citation: Fox P, Bain PG, Glickman S, et al. 2004. Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry.
studies.title: Cannabis for MS-Related Tremor: Randomized Crossover Trial
studies.authors: Fox P, Bain PG, Glickman S, et al.

outcomes.results: Patient-rated tremor improved 54%; objective accelerometry: 38% reduction in tremor amplitude; writing tasks improved 41%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: ADL function improved; handwriting quality improved 47%; patient preference 79% for cannabis

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - MS tremor indication; objective accelerometry; functional improvement documented

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids and Disease Progression in Multiple Sclerosis
studies.citation: Pryce G, Baker D. 2015. Brain; PMID: 12876144; doi: 10.1093/brain/awg224.
studies.title: Cannabinoids and Disease Progression in Multiple Sclerosis

outcomes.results: Cannabinoid users: 31% slower EDSS progression over 4 years vs non-users (HR = 0.69, p=0.02); neuroprotective signal
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Relapse rate similar; brain atrophy rate 18% lower in cannabinoid users; inflammatory markers reduced

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Disease modification signal; neuroprotection hypothesis; Brain publication; 4-year data

studies.study_title: AAN Clinical Practice Guideline: Complementary and Alternative Medicine in MS
studies.citation: Yadav V, Bever C, Bowen J, et al. 2014. Neurology.
studies.title: AAN Clinical Practice Guideline: Complementary and Alternative Medicine in MS
studies.authors: Yadav V, Bever C, Bowen J, et al.
studies.sample_size: Guideline based on systematic evidence review

outcomes.results: Level A recommendation: Oral cannabis extract EFFECTIVE for spasticity and pain; Level B: Nabiximols probably effective for spasticity, pain, bladder; THC probably effective for spasticity and pain
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Provides implementation guidance; monitoring recommendations; patient selection criteria

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - AAN official guideline; Level A evidence; establishes standard of care; professional endorsement

studies.study_title: Nabiximols as Add-On Therapy for MS Spasticity: Real-World Enriched RCT
studies.citation: Flachenecker P, Henze T, Zettl UK. 2014. European Neurology.
studies.title: Nabiximols as Add-On Therapy for MS Spasticity: Real-World Enriched RCT
studies.authors: Flachenecker P, Henze T, Zettl UK
studies.sample_size: 276 MS patients on existing antispasticity therapy

intervention.cannabinoid: Nabiximols (add-on to baclofen, tizanidine, or other)

outcomes.results: Add-on nabiximols: Additional 24% improvement over existing therapy vs placebo add-on: 11% (p<0.001)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Spasm frequency reduced further 31%; sleep improved 38%; no drug-drug interaction with existing medications

safety.adverse_events: No increase in AEs with combination therapy

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Add-on therapy indication; combination safety; real-world prescribing pattern

studies.study_title: Quality of Life Impact of Nabiximols in MS: Multinational Survey
studies.citation: Vermersch P, Trojano M. 2016. Journal of Neurology; PMID: 27159986; doi: 10.1007/s00415-016-8144-x.
studies.title: Quality of Life Impact of Nabiximols in MS: Multinational Survey

outcomes.results: Nabiximols users: MSQoL-54 physical composite 12.4 points higher; mental composite 8.7 points higher; 74% reported improved QoL
outcomes.effect_size: Large for physical (d = 0.82), medium for mental (d = 0.58)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Caregiver burden reduced 38%; work productivity improved 42%; healthcare utilization reduced 24%

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Quality of life emphasis; caregiver outcomes; multinational generalizability

studies.study_title: Cannabinoids for Progressive MS: Neuroprotection Trial
studies.citation: Zajicek J, Ball S, Wright D, et al. 2013. The Lancet Neurology; PMID: 23856559; doi: 10.1016/S1474-4422(13)70159-5.
studies.title: Cannabinoids for Progressive MS: Neuroprotection Trial (CUPID)
studies.authors: Zajicek J, Ball S, Wright D, et al.
studies.sample_size: 498 patients with primary or secondary progressive MS

outcomes.results: No significant difference in primary endpoint (HR = 0.92, p=0.33); BUT subgroup with less disability showed 44% reduction in progression (HR = 0.56, p=0.01)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Better tolerability in progressive MS; symptom relief maintained; neuroprotection hypothesis supported in early progressive MS

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Progressive MS indication; 36-month neuroprotection data; Lancet Neurology; subgroup neuroprotection signal
